revision.text:
The '''2016 Virginia Scholastic and College Championships''' was a Chess Tournament<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vschess.org/about-virginia-chess/|title=VSCA {{!}} About the Virginia Scholastic Chess Association|website=www.vschess.org|access-date=2016-03-10}}</ref> held March 4–6, 2016, in [[Ashburn, Virginia]]. The categories included K-3, K-5, K-8, K-12 and College groups.<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://vachess.org/ |title=Virginia Chess Federation |website=Vachess.org |date= |accessdate=2016-03-08}}</ref>
Nearly 100 students from elementary, middle and high schools across the state competed in the tournament at West Virginia State University. Winners go on to compete in national tournaments later in the year.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/article/20160305/GZ01/160309664|title=Charleston Gazette-Mail - *Students test chess skills in tournament|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail}}</ref>
==K-8 player== *Ryan Xu * Andy Huang *Trung Q Nguyen *Alex Jian * Zhengan Chen *Issac Chin * Andrew Wang
==K-12 player== *Jenniffer Yu *Bryan Zhao *Boyoung Zhao *Erick Rendon <ref name="auto"/> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uschess.org/msa/XtblMain.php?201603066132.3 |title=US Chess MSA - Cross Table for VIRGINIA SCHOLASTIC AND COLLEGE CHAMPIONSHIPS (Event 201603066132) |website=Uschess.org |date=2003-10-16 |accessdate=2016-03-08}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Acklam Park | image = Acklam Park Front Of The Ground.jpg | fullname = Acklam Park | address = Green Lane, TS5 7SL | location = [[Middlesbrough, England]] | type = [[Sports venue]] | capacity = 5,000 (159 seated) | surface = Grass | broke ground = 1928 | built = 1928–1929 | opened = 1929 | renovated = 2008 | yearsactive = 1929–1940, 1945–present | cost = £1,200 (1929) | tenants = [[Middlesbrough RUFC]] (1929–present)
Middlesbrough CC (1932–present) }} '''Acklam Park''' is a [[rugby union]] and [[cricket]] ground located in [[Middlesbrough]], [[North Yorkshire]], [[England]].{{cite web|url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57173.html|title=Acklam Park - England - Cricket Grounds|publisher=ESPN Cricinfo|accessdate=29 September 2017}} Initially opened in 1929, the venue has hosted games of [[Middlesbrough RUFC]] since the ground's opening as well as Middlesbrough Cricket Club since 1932. [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club]] have also played a number of first class matches at Acklam Park over the years from 1956 to 1996. With a capacity of 5,000, the ground initially cost the rugby club £1,200. ==History== [[Middlesbrough RUFC]] purchased a 12-acre field in 1928 for a fee of £1,200.{{cite web|url=http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/middlesbroughrufcminis-juniors/a/history-8206.html?page=3|title=Information - Middlesbrough RUFC|publisher=Pitchero – MRUFC|accessdate=29 September 2017}} The club paid 13 [[shillings]], club members paid £500 and £800 was loaned from the [[Rugby Football Union]]. Middlesbrough played their first games on their present ground in 1929 having played at several previous venues. Due to the cost of the ground, the club officials began selling oats and wheat from the field in order to pay off their loan from the RFU. The name Acklam Park was adopted in 1930, and the following year a stand and pavilion were built, funded as a result of 12 interest-free loans of £100 each from local businessmen, the majority of whom refused to take repayment of their loan. In 1932, Middlesbrough CC became joint-owners of Acklam Park. With play halted during [[World War II]], the ground close in 1940, before being re-opened in 1945. In 2008, a new clubhouse was opened at Acklam Park, which includes a bar, a café, a gym, a function room and lounge. Changing and shower rooms were also inserted, which leads out to an exit to the main cricket and rugby pitches. Seats are placed in front of the changing rooms exit and café door exit facing a clear view of the cricket pitch and a view of one of two rugby pitches on the left-hand side. Despite seats, supporters are eligible to stand and watch the rugby team play. There is also a stand facing the first team pitch, with the stand featuring the name "Middlesbrough Rugby Club". The stand uses bench seating rather than plastic seating. In 2017, it was announced that the club aimed to have plastic seats added into their stand. In August 2018, the club added dug-outs to the first team pitch. ==Location== The ground sits on Green Lane Avenue, and is located near [[Acklam Hall]]. The ground is located near Acklam Shops, and there is a range of pubs near ground, in which the away supporters can have other hospitality. Next door to the ground, there is a care home. ==Other events== Annually, a summer beer festival is held at the ground, which has raised much money over the years. They also host an annual firework display. On 27 August 2017, the ground hosted a fundraiser event, ''Party in Acklam Park!'', with live music and entertainment.{{cite web|title=Party in Acklam Park! festival|url=https://www.skiddle.com/festivals/partyinacklampark/|publisher=Skiddle|accessdate=30 September 2017}} The purpose of this event was to raise more money for the club, for new developments in the youth teams. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.pitchero.com/clubs/middlesbroughrufcminis-juniors/a/history-8206.html?page=3/ Middlesbrough RUFC] * [http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57173.html/ Middlesbrough CC] [[Category:Sports venues in Middlesbrough]] [[Category:Rugby union stadiums in England]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1929]] [[Category:1929 establishments in England]] [[Category:Cricket grounds in England]]

{{about|the arena|the subway station|Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center (New York City Subway)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Barclays Center | logo_image = [[File:BarclaysCenterLogo.png|125px]] | image = Barclays Center western side.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = The western entrance of Barclays Center from the corner of Atlantic Avenue and Flatbush Avenue | address = 620 [[Atlantic Avenue (New York City)|Atlantic Avenue]] | location = [[Brooklyn|Brooklyn, New York]] | coordinates = {{Coord|40|40|57.58|N|73|58|30.81|W|}} | broke_ground = March 11, 2010{{cite news |title=Atlantic Yards Ground-Breaking Event Marked By Politicians, Pop Star and Protests|first=Erin|last=Durkin|first2=Bill|last2=Hutchinson|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/03/11/2010-03-11_atlantic_yards_groundbreaking_event_marked_by_politicians_pop_stars_and_protests.html|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=March 11, 2010|accessdate=March 11, 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100314034201/http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/03/11/2010-03-11_atlantic_yards_groundbreaking_event_marked_by_politicians_pop_stars_and_protests.html|archivedate=March 14, 2010|deadurl=no}} | opened = September 21, 2012 ([[National Basketball Association|NBA]])

(joint venture between [[Forest City Enterprises]] and [[Mikhail Prokhorov#ONEXIM Group|ONEXIM Sports & Entertainment]])) | operator = [[Anschutz Entertainment Group|AEG Live]] | architect = [[AECOM]] ([[Ellerbe Becket]])

[[New York Islanders]] ([[National Hockey League|NHL]]) (2015–present)
[[Long Island Nets]] ([[NBA Development League|NBA D-League]]) (2016–2017) | website ={{URL|www.barclayscenter.com}} | cost = US$1 billion{{cite news|title=The NBA Comes to WWE Summerslam Brooklyn |url=http://www.constructiondigital.com/under_construction/the-nba-comes-to-brooklyn |work=Construction Digital |date=August 1, 2011 |accessdate=August 4, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111018113358/http://www.constructiondigital.com/under_construction/the-nba-comes-to-brooklyn |archivedate=October 18, 2011 |df=mdy }} | publictransit = *[[Long Island Rail Road]]: [[Atlantic Terminal]]
{{rail color box|system=LIRR|line=City Atlantic}} *[[New York City Subway]]: [[Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center (New York City Subway)|Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center]] ({{NYCS Atlantic-Barclays|time=bullets}}) *[[MTA Regional Bus Operations]]: {{NYC bus link|B37|B41|B45|B63|B65|B67|B103}} }} '''Barclays Center''' is a multi-purpose [[list of indoor arenas|indoor arena]] in the [[New York City]] [[Borough (New York City)|borough]] of [[Brooklyn]]. The arena is part of a $4.9 billion future [[commerce|business]] and [[residential area|residential]] complex now known as [[Pacific Park, Brooklyn|Pacific Park]].{{cite web|title=About Atlantic Yards |url=http://www.esd.ny.gov/Subsidiaries_Projects/AYP/AYAboutUs.html |publisher=[[Empire State Development Corporation]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919030221/http://esd.ny.gov/subsidiaries_projects/AYP/AYAboutUs.html |archivedate=September 19, 2012 |df=mdy }} The site is at [[Atlantic Avenue (New York City)|Atlantic Avenue]], next to the renamed [[Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center (New York City Subway)|Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center]] subway station on the {{NYCS trains|Atlantic-Pacific|type=route}}, as well as directly above the [[Long Island Rail Road|LIRR]]'s [[Atlantic Terminal]]. The arena is home to the [[Brooklyn Nets]] of the [[National Basketball Association]], and is also one of the home arenas for the [[New York Islanders]] of the [[National Hockey League]] (the other is [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]]).{{cite news |url=http://espn.go.com/new-york/nba/story/_/id/7022025/jay-z-announces-brooklyn-nets-name-concert|title=Jay-Z: Team to be Brooklyn Nets|first=Christopher|last=Hunt|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=September 26, 2011|accessdate=September 26, 2011}}{{cite news|last=Honan|first=Edith|title=New York Islanders to move to Brooklyn in 2015|url=http://ca.reuters.com/article/sportsNews/idCABRE89N1B420121024|agency=Reuters Canada|accessdate=October 24, 2012|date=October 24, 2012}} The arena also hosts concerts, conventions and other sporting and entertainment events. It competes with other facilities in the New York metropolitan area, including [[Madison Square Garden]] in [[Manhattan]] and [[Prudential Center]] in [[Newark, New Jersey|Newark]]. The arena, proposed in 2004 when real estate developer [[Bruce Ratner]] purchased the Nets for $300 million as the first step of the process to build a new home for the team,{{cite news |title=Brooklyn Developer Reaches Deal to Buy New Jersey Nets|first1=Richard|last1=Sandomir|first2=Charles V.|last2=Bagli|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/21/sports/basketball/21CND-NETS.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 21, 2004|accessdate=October 4, 2012}} experienced significant hurdles during its development. Its use of [[eminent domain]] and its potential environmental impact{{cite news|url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/topic/55684/|title=Intelligencer: Atlantic Yards, Inch by Inch|date=March 29, 2009|publisher= New York magazine}} brought community resistance, especially as residential buildings and businesses such as the [[Ward Baking Company Building|Ward Bakery]] were to be demolished and large amounts of public subsidies were used, which led to multiple lawsuits. The [[Great Recession|global recession of 2009]] also caused financing for the project to dry up. As a result, construction was delayed until 2010, with no secure funding for the project having been allotted. [[Groundbreaking]] for construction occurred on March 11, 2010, and the arena opened on September 21, 2012, which was also attended by some 200 protesters. It held its first event with a [[Jay-Z]] concert on September 28, 2012.{{cite web|title=Barclay's Center Opens In Brooklyn |url=http://nymn.com/barclays-center-opens-in-brooklyn-with-jay-z-new-york-music-news/ |publisher=[[nymn.com]] |date=September 28, 2012 |accessdate=September 28, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121004031713/http://nymn.com/barclays-center-opens-in-brooklyn-with-jay-z-new-york-music-news/ |archivedate=October 4, 2012 }} The arena and the Brooklyn Nets are owned by [[Mikhail Prokhorov]]'s American holdings. ==History== The arena was conceived by [[Bruce Ratner]] of real estate developer [[Forest City Ratner|Forest City Ratner Companies]], the New York division of [[Forest City Enterprises]] that Ratner founded. He acquired the New Jersey Nets basketball team in 2004 for $300 million (he has since sold most of his shares to continue funding the project) for the purpose of moving them to the [[Pacific Park, Brooklyn|Pacific Park]] development on Brooklyn's [[Prospect Heights, Brooklyn|Prospect Heights]] play in the arena that would be the centerpiece of the Pacific Park commercial and residential redevelopment project. The move had marked the return of [[Major professional sports leagues in the United States and Canada|major league]] sports to Brooklyn, which had been absent since the departure of the [[History of the Brooklyn Dodgers|Dodgers]] to Los Angeles in 1957. Coincidentally, the original proposal for a [[Brooklyn Dodgers proposed domed stadium|domed stadium for the Brooklyn Dodgers]] was just north of the Pacific Park Brooklyn site, where the [[Atlantic Terminal Mall]], also owned by Forest City Ratner Companies, is located. [[Image:Barclays-Center-6-19-11.jpg|thumb|left|alt=A photograph of Barclays Center under construction.|Barclays Center during construction June 19, 2011.{{cite web |title=Barclay's Center|url=http://www.barclayscenter.com|accessdate=June 11, 2011| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707212353/http://www.barclayscenter.com/| archivedate= July 7, 2011| deadurl=no}}]] The arena was initially projected to open in 2006, with the rest of the Pacific Park Brooklyn complex to follow. However, controversies involving local residents, the use of [[eminent domain]], potential environmental impact, lack of continued public financing, as well as a major economic downturn delayed the project.{{cite news |title=Nets Say Brooklyn Move May Be Delayed Further|agency=Associated Press|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/04/sports/basketball/04nba.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=January 4, 2008|accessdate=October 20, 2010}} Due to these legal and financial troubles, the development deal seemed headed towards failure or collapse.{{cite news |title=No Red Dawn for Ratner|first=Will|last=Leitch|url=http://nymag.com/news/intelligencer/51834/|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]|date=November 2, 2008}} [[Frank Gehry]], an architect involved in the project's initial designs said, in March 2009, "I don't think it is going to happen," and Ratner at one point explored selling the team.{{cite news |title=Bruce Ratner Explored Nets Sale|first=Frank|last=Isola|author2=Lawrence, Mitch|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/basketball/nets/2008/10/27/2008-10-27_bruce_ratner_explored_nets_sale.html|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=October 27, 2008}} The [[New York Supreme Court]] ruled in favor of Ratner on May 16, 2009.{{Clarify|date=February 2014}} Opponents appealed the court decision. A hearing for the appeal was scheduled for October 14, 2009, with a decision to be issued no sooner than November 25.{{cite news |title=The Court Date Is Set for Atlantic Yards in Brooklyn|first=Ryan|last=Thompson|url=http://www.brooklyneagle.com/categories/category.php?category_id=26&id=29432|newspaper=[[Brooklyn Eagle|Brooklyn Daily Eagle]]|date=July 9, 2009|accessdate=September 10, 2009}} Russian businessman [[Mikhail Prokhorov]] agreed to a $200 million deal on September 23, 2009, to become a principal owner of the Nets and a key investor in the Brooklyn arena.{{citation needed|date=December 2013}} The Nets played two preseason games at [[Prudential Center]] in October 2009.{{cite web |title=Prudential Center To Host New Jersey Nets Pre-Season Basketball|url=http://www.prucenter.com/default.asp?prucenter=107&objId=73|publisher=Prudential Center's Official Website|date=March 4, 2009|accessdate=March 19, 2009|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090315001553/http://www.prucenter.com/default.asp?prucenter=107&objId=73|archivedate=March 15, 2009|deadurl=no}} The two preseason games were successful, and a deal that would have the Nets play at the Prudential Center for the 2010–11 and 2011–12 NBA seasons became more likely. Negotiations nearly fell apart, when the New Jersey Sports and Exhibition Authority refused to release the Nets from their lease at Izod.{{cite news |title=Deal to Move NJ Nets to Newark's Prudential Center Falls Apart|first=Ted|last=Sherman|url=http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2009/12/newark_prudential_center_izod.html|newspaper=[[The Star-Ledger]]|location=Newark|date=December 16, 2009|accessdate=December 19, 2009}} Negotiations resumed, and on February 18, 2010, the Nets finalized a deal that would move them to the Prudential Center in [[Newark, New Jersey]] until Barclays Center opened. The [[New York Court of Appeals]] ruled in favor of the state using eminent domain for the project on November 24, 2009. [[Empire State Development Corporation]] Vice President Warner Johnston indicated that the agency is committed to seeing the project completed and said "we can now move forward with development."{{cite news |title=New York Court of Appeals Rules State Can Use Eminent Domain to Take Land for Atlantic Yards Arena Project|url=http://www.nj.com/nets/index.ssf/2009/11/new_york_court_of_appeals_rule.html|newspaper=[[The Star-Ledger]]|location=Newark|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=November 24, 2009|accessdate=February 7, 2010}} Another potential roadblock to this development resulted from the Appellate Court's negative decision regarding a similar eminent domain case, brought against Columbia University.{{cite news |title=No Eminent Domain for Columbia University Expansion: Court|first=Jose|last=Martinez|first2=Frank|last2=Lombardi|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/real_estate/2009/12/04/2009-12-04_columbia_land_grab_nixed_no_eminent_domain_for_university_expansion_court.html|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]|date=December 4, 2009|accessdate=February 6, 2010}} This landmark case could have given new life to the case being brought by the community group Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn (DDDB). [[File:Bklyn Nets arena Feb 2012 jeh.jpg|thumb|left|February 2012, just seven months before construction was finished]] However, on March 1, 2010, Brooklyn Supreme Court Justice Abraham Gerges struck down a challenge by property owners, regarding the state's use of eminent domain, which allowed the private property to be condemned. Groundbreaking for the project occurred on March 11, 2010. The first concrete was poured into Barclays Center's foundation on June 29, 2010.{{cite news|title=Work Begins on Concrete Foundation for Nets new Brooklyn Home |first=Josh |last=Brennan |url=http://www.northjersey.com/sports/pro_sports/97427054.html |newspaper=[[The Record (Bergen County)|The Record]] |date=June 29, 2010 |accessdate=June 30, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110603170433/http://www.northjersey.com/sports/pro_sports/97427054.html |archivedate=June 3, 2011 |df=mdy }} The arena began vertical construction on November 23, 2010, with the erection of the first steel piece.{{cite news |title=Steel for the Barclays Center in Brooklyn Begins to go Vertical|url=http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Barclays_Steel_Release_101123.html|newspaper=New Jersey Nets News|date=November 23, 2010|accessdate=November 23, 2010|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101123213833/http://www.nba.com/nets/news/Barclays_Steel_Release_101123.html|archivedate=November 23, 2010|deadurl=no}} The arena topped out on January 12, 2012, and was opened to the public on September 21, 2012. [[Barclays Bank]] agreed to a 20-year naming rights agreement for $400 million in 2007. However, 2 years later, due to the slump in the economy the deal was renegotiated to $200 million.{{cite web |last1=Calder |first1=Rich |title=Barclays Center makes it official |url=https://nypost.com/2012/08/08/barclays-center-makes-it-official/ |website=New York Post |accessdate=September 2, 2018 |date=August 8, 2012}} The [[New York Islanders]] of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) announced on October 24, 2012, that the franchise would move to Barclays Center in 2015 after the expiration of their lease at the [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]], which the team has called home since its inception in 1972. The deal did not require the involvement of the [[New York Rangers]], as the Islanders' agreement with the Rangers to share the New York area allows them to play their home games anywhere on Long Island, including the two city boroughs on the island, Brooklyn and [[Queens]].{{cite news |title=New York Islanders Ponder Move to Willets Point|first=Connor Adams|last=Sheets|url=http://yournabe.com/articles/2010/05/20/astoria_times/news/at_islanders_willets_pt_20100520.txt|newspaper=Astoria Times|date=May 20, 2010|accessdate=2010-05-30}} While Barclays Center was conceived as a multipurpose arena that could accommodate the Nets and an NHL team, it was built mainly for basketball. While it can accommodate an NHL-size rink, the scoreboard was off-centered above the blue line that is closer to the arena's southeast end. Capacity for hockey is 15,795, the second-smallest in the league (behind [[Winnipeg Jets|Winnipeg]]'s [[MTS Centre]]). The seating arrangement for hockey is asymmetrical. There are only three rows of permanent seating on the northwest end of the arena, and at least 416 seats will not be sold at all due to poor sight lines.{{cite news |title=Everything You Need to Know About Barclays Center's Hockey Configuration|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2013/09/barclays-centers-hockey-details.html|newspaper=New York Magazine|date=Sep 13, 2013|accessdate=2010-09-13}} As a result of the signing of the lease, the two [[Kontinental Hockey League|KHL]] games scheduled to be played in the arena on January 20 and 21, 2013 between [[HC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]] and [[SKA Saint Petersburg|SKA St. Petersburg]] were moved back to their teams' home venues. As part of the deal, the management of the Barclays Center took over the business operations of the Islanders when the team moved to Brooklyn, though [[Charles Wang]] remained principal owner and continued to oversee hockey operations.{{cite news|last=Kosman |first=Josh |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/so_like_isles_start_lookin_like_CXMENQtTB5PWxOamOgIYLO |title=Islanders may change team colors with move to Brooklyn |work=New York Post |date=2013-04-25 |accessdate=2013-08-13}} This arrangement continued after Wang sold controlling interest in the Islanders to [[Jon Ledecky]] and [[Scott D. Malkin]]. According to ''[[Billboard Magazine]]'', Barclays Center passed [[Madison Square Garden]] as the highest-grossing venue in the US for concerts and family shows, not counting sports events. That statistic was based on ticket sales between November 1, 2012, and May 31, 2013.{{cite news|title=Garden wilting at No. 2 as Barclays Center named highest-grossing venue in US|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/garden_wilting_at_no_WroErVTTwgNulGVBhiA4BM|publisher=NY Post|accessdate=24 July 2013|first=David K.|last=Li}} On February 24, 2015, an ironworker was killed when four joists fell on him as he was helping to install the arena's green roof.{{cite news|title=Iron worker at Barclays Center crushed to death by steel beams: police|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/brooklyn/worker-barclays-center-crushed-death-steel-beams-article-1.2128317|publisher=NY Daily News|date=25 February 2015|first=Kerry|last=Burke}} Poor reception of the arena's quality as a hockey venue affected the Islanders' average attendance in comparison to Nassau Coliseum, which fell to an NHL low of 12,059 (the arena itself is also the second-smallest in the league). The team began to seek an exit from Barclays, although NHL officials judged that the Coliseum (even with its recent renovations) would not be suitable as a full-time venue, as it lacked amenities common in new facilities.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/islanders-making-their-move-to-brooklyns-barclays-center-1435625418|title=Barclays Center to Finally Break the Ice With Islanders, Fans|last=Caldwell|first=Dave|date=2015-06-30|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} {{subscription required}}{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/23/barclays-pressuring-islanders-into-more-coliseum-games/|title=Barclays pressuring Islanders into more Coliseum games|date=2018-01-23|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-01-24|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2017/09/09/nhl-on-islanders-nassau-coliseum-hopes-keep-dreaming/|title=NHL on Islanders’ Nassau Coliseum hopes: Keep dreaming|date=2017-09-09|work=New York Post|access-date=2017-10-03|language=en-US}} On June 21, 2018, the Islanders announced that they would begin to play a portion of their home schedule at the Nassau Coliseum until the completion of their new [[Belmont Park Arena]] project.{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/nhl/story/_/id/22254786/new-york-islanders-split-home-games-nassau-coliseum-barclays|title=Net return: Isles get 12 home games at Nassau|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-11-17|language=en}} ==Financing== The arena is formally owned by the Brooklyn Arena Local Development Corporation, a public entity. It is leased to private entity Brooklyn Events Center, LLC for $1.00.{{cite news|url=http://www.esd.ny.gov/Subsidiaries_Projects/AYP/AtlanticYards/ModifiedGPP2009.pdf |title=Atlantic Yards Land Use Improvement and Civic Project Modified General Project Plan |date=June 23, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160207185933/http://esd.ny.gov/Subsidiaries_Projects/AYP/AtlanticYards/ModifiedGPP2009.pdf |archivedate=February 7, 2016 |df=mdy }} Being publicly owned, the financing of the stadium was eligible for tax-exempt bonds, which were issued in 2009 for a total of $510,999,996.50.{{cite news|url=http://emma.msrb.org/EP374892-EP290943-EP686334.pdf|title=Brooklyn Arena Local Development Corporation PILOT Revenue Bonds, Series 2009 (Barclays Center Project)|date=December 16, 2009}} ==Design== [[File:Barclays Center Oculus.jpg|thumb|right|The Barclays Center oculus, with a view of the LCD screen inside the structure]] [[File:Barclays Center Boston Celtics-Brooklyn Nets 2012.jpg|thumb|right|Interior view of the Barclays Center during an NBA game]] Barclays Center was designed by the architect firm [[SHoP Architects]]. [[Ellerbe Becket|Ellerbe Becket/AECOM]] served as the project [[Architect of record]]. Initial concepts for the area were designed by [[Frank Gehry]], whose design proposed a rooftop park (open only to residents of the Atlantic Yards complex) ringed by an open-air [[Track and field|running track]] and capable of doubling as an [[Ice rink|ice skating rink]] in winter with [[panoramic]], year-round views of [[Manhattan]]. The famed architect's tallest tower, called Miss Brooklyn at 620 feet, was also part of this plan. Gehry's plans carried a projected cost of $1 billion. Forest City Ratner unveiled a scaled back version of the project on February 2008 reducing Miss Brooklyn's size 40%, and making it 109 feet shorter. Another redesign unveiled just over two months later scrapped Miss Brooklyn entirely, and in January 2009, the developer started "value engineering" the arena design, cutting its budget even more. In September 2009 the Becket/SHoP proposal with a projected cost (initially) of $800 million (ultimately itself revised to $1 billion) was unveiled. Externally, the arena's shape features three articulated bands with features a glass [[Curtain wall (architecture)|curtain wall]] covered by a "latticework" composed of 12,000 [[Weathering steel|preweathered steel]] panels engineered and constructed by ASI Limited/SHoP Construction{{cite news| url=http://archrecord.construction.com/projects/building_types_study/stadiums/2012/barclays-center-shop.asp?specs=true|title=Architectural Record: Barclays Center}} meant to evoke the image of Brooklyn's [[Brownstone#Brownstone dwellings|brownstones]].{{cite web |url=http://www.shop-construction.com/#/projects/featured/barclayscenter|title=Barclays Center|work=SHoP Construction|accessdate=October 20, 2011}} A {{convert|117|by|56|ft|m|adj=on}} [[oculus]] extends over a {{convert|5660|sqft|m2|adj=on}} section of the plaza outside of the main arena entrance with an irregularly shaped display screen looping the interior face of the oculus.{{cite press release|title=Plaza at Barclays Center to Include New Transit Entrance with Green Roof, Landscaping and Open Space for Community Programming |url=http://barclayscenter.com/press/articles/plaza_at_barclays.shtml |publisher=Barclays Center |date=September 28, 2010 |accessdate=October 20, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111016140620/http://barclayscenter.com/press/articles/plaza_at_barclays.shtml |archivedate=October 16, 2011 |df=mdy }} The arena floor's location below grade allows people in the plaza to view the scoreboard. Inside the arena bowl, there are two sports lighting systems: one for the Nets and one for everyone else.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10000872396390443854204578056850231139058|title=No, You Can't Use the Nets' Specialized Lighting System|last=Cacciola|first=Scott|date=2012-10-15|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|issn=0099-9660|access-date=2016-06-09}} The Nets lighting creates a theater-like effect where the court pops like a stage while the rest of the arena goes dark. Unlike most other urban venues in the US, Barclays Center has no dedicated parking lot; however, it is easily accessible by [[New York City Subway|subway]], [[MTA Regional Bus Operations|bus]], and [[Long Island Rail Road|railroad]].{{cite web | title = 6 ways to maximize home-field advantage in sports venue design | publisher = Building Design + Construction, Jon Niemuth, September 26, 2013 | url = http://www.bdcnetwork.com/6-ways-maximize-home-field-advantage-sports-venue-design}} To accommodate entry to the facility, the arena's {{convert|38885|sqft|m2|adj=on|0}} entrance plaza features a $76 million transit connection hub{{cite news|title=With Federal Case and Modular Building Plan, New Attention for Atlantic Yards Project|first=Charles V.|last=Bagli|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/18/nyregion/18yards.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=March 17, 2011}} that serves as the plaza's focal point. The transit structure connects with the refurbished [[Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center (New York City Subway)|Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center subway station]], whose renovation was designed by New York City firm Stantec. The original plan promised indoor room for bicycles but the plan was scrapped before the arena's opening with outdoor racks for 400 bicycles, which were eventually taken away. The Empire State Development corporation also promised spots for 550 cars eventually, next to the arena{{Where|date=July 2015}}.{{cite news|url=http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120507/prospect-heights/no-indoor-bike-parking-for-barclays-center-opening|title=No Indoor Bike Parking for Barclays Center Opening|date=May 7, 2012|publisher=DNAinfo.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140323081335/http://www.dnainfo.com/new-york/20120507/prospect-heights/no-indoor-bike-parking-for-barclays-center-opening|archivedate=March 23, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Because of the constrained site, there are only two truck and bus entrances into the building. They consist of two side-by-side {{convert|80000|lb|kg}} capacity elevators which lower vehicles {{convert|35|ft|m}} below street grade into a loading dock area. Vehicles roll out onto an enormous turntable which rotates them into position opposite one of four loading docks arrayed around the turntable.Steve Romnes, [http://www.meielevatorsolutions.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/04/BARCLAYS-CENTER.pdf Barclays Center Freight Elevators], ''Elevator World'', April 2015, p. 84-87. ===Artwork=== [[File:2013 Parla working at Barclays Center.jpg|thumb|Artist José Parla working on the mural ''Diary of Brooklyn'' in the Barclays Center]] The building features the mural ''Diary of Brooklyn'' by painter [[José Parlá]], which measures 10 feet wide and 70 feet tall. According to Parlá, the painting is all about language; the painting contains words and phrases such as "immigration," "Brooklyn is" and "Big Daddy Kane." The piece was commissioned in 2012 and took six months to complete.{{cite news |last=Murphy |first=Tim |date=12 June 2013 |title=José Parlá, Barclays Center Muralist |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/06/13/fashion/jose-parla-barclays-center-muralist.html?mtrref=www.google.es |work=New York Times |access-date= 28 January 2018}} ==Naming rights== [[File:Barclays-center.jpg|thumb|left|Seen in 2018]] On January 18, 2007, it was announced that the arena would be called Barclays Center, after London-based banking group [[Barclays]]. It was reported that the banking and financial services company agreed to pay the team $400 million over the next 20 years for the [[naming rights]] of their Brooklyn home,{{cite news |title=Nets' New Arena Reportedly To Be Called "Barclays Center"|url=http://www.ny1.com/?SecID=1000&ArID=65958|work=NY1|date=January 17, 2007|accessdate=July 1, 2010}} eclipsing the previous record for naming rights to an American indoor arena, set by [[Royal Philips Electronics]] in 1999, for $185 million over 20 years for [[Philips Arena]] in Atlanta. However, the rights were renegotiated by the end of 2009, and are somewhat more than $200 million.{{cite news |title=Nets Arena in Brooklyn Atlantic Yards Fends Off Challenge|first=Charles V.|last=Bagli|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/02/nyregion/02yards.html|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 12, 2009|accessdate=June 9, 2010}}{{cite web |title=Barclays Center Project POS|page=80|url=https://www.scribd.com/doc/23597152/Barclays-Center-Project-POS|accessdate=June 9, 2010}} Barclays does not have any retail banks in the US nor does it have its own ATMs in the arena.{{cite news |title=Barclays Has No Game Despite Its $400M Arena Deal|first=Mark|last=Decambre|url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/business/banking_airball_Y0KPqD89vF37VR9XCAp8XI#ixzz2739Ws9Iu|newspaper=[[New York Post]]|date=September 20, 2012|accessdate=September 22, 2012}} ==Accessibility and transportation== Barclays Center is located next to [[Atlantic Terminal]], which services the [[Long Island Rail Road]]'s [[Atlantic Branch]]. Barclays Center is also accessible via the [[New York City Subway]], via the {{NYCS trains|Atlantic-Barclays}}, which stop at [[Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center (New York City Subway)|Atlantic Avenue–Barclays Center]].{{NYCS const|map}} [[MTA Regional Bus Operations]] service is provided by {{NYC bus link|B37|B41|B45|B63|B65|B67}}, and {{NYC bus link|B103}} buses.{{Cite NYC bus map|B}} ==Notable events== ===Basketball=== [[File:Boston Celtics-Brooklyn Nets.jpg|thumb|right|The Brooklyn Nets playing against the [[Boston Celtics]] in 2012]] The first NBA basketball game played at the new arena was an NBA preseason game between the Nets and the [[Washington Wizards]] on October 15, 2012.{{cite news |url=http://www.nba.com/nets/schedule|title=Nets Schedule|publisher=Brooklyn Nets|accessdate=September 24, 2012}} The first regular season NBA game at the Barclays Center took place on November 3, 2012, when the Nets beat the visiting [[Toronto Raptors]] 107–100. The originally scheduled season opener home game was supposed to take place on November 1 against now-cross town rivals the [[New York Knicks]], in what was planned to be a historic event; however, the game was canceled by NYC Mayor [[Michael Bloomberg]] due to mass transportation outages and a shortage of available police caused by [[Hurricane Sandy]].{{cite news |url=http://observer.com/2012/10/nets-dunked-by-sandy-mayor-bloomberg-cancels-thursdays-nets-knicks-opener-at-barclays-center |title=Nets Dunked By Sandy |work=New York Observer |accessdate=December 13, 2012}} The venue hosted the [[NBA Draft]] starting with the [[2013 NBA draft]] on June 27, 2013{{cite web|title=2013 NBA Draft will be held in Brooklyn at the Barclays Center|url=http://www.cbssports.com/nba/blog/eye-on-basketball/22132413/2013-nba-draft-will-be-held-in-brooklyn-at-the-barclays-center|publisher=CBS Sports|accessdate=April 24, 2013}} and will remain as the host for the [[2017 NBA Draft]]. In addition to that, they have also hosted the [[2015 NBA All-Star Game|2015]] [[NBA All-Star Weekend]] festivities on February 13–14, 2015. Barclays Center was also the home for the [[Long Island Nets]] of the [[NBA Development League]] during the 2016–17 season while the [[Nassau Veterans Memorial Coliseum]] was being renovated for the 2017–18 season. ====College basketball==== Since its opening, the center has hosted a number of college basketball events. [[Kentucky Wildcats men's basketball|Kentucky]] and [[Maryland Terrapins men's basketball|Maryland]] signed multi-year agreements to play games at the arena after competing head-to-head in 2012.{{cite news| url=http://www.nydailynews.com/sports/college/kentucky-maryland-multi-year-deal-play-barclays-center-article-1.1290820 |title=Kentucky and Maryland agree to multi-year agreements to play games at Barclays Center in Brooklyn |last=Brennan|first=Sean | work=[[New York Daily News]]}} The arena hosts three early-season basketball tournaments: [[Barclays Center Classic]], [[Coaches vs. Cancer Classic]], and [[Legends Classic (basketball tournament)|Legends Classic]]. The [[Atlantic 10 Conference]] announced that Barclays Center will be the new home of the conference's men's basketball tournament beginning in 2013.{{cite news |last=Katz |first=Andy |title=A-10 to hold tourney at Barclays |url=http://espn.go.com/mens-college-basketball/story/_/id/7022534/atlantic-10-moving-conference-tournament-new-jersey-nets-arena |date=September 27, 2011 |accessdate=September 27, 2011}} The [[Atlantic Coast Conference]] has announced that the 2017 and 2018 [[ACC Men's Basketball Tournament]] will be hosted at the Barclays Center. This is a break of tradition from being hosted at the "unofficial" home of the tournament at the [[Greensboro Coliseum]] in [[Greensboro, North Carolina]] where it is usually held.[http://www.wralsportsfan.com/acc-postseason-tourney-headed-to-brooklyn-in-2017-2018/13513212/ ACC: Postseason tourney headed to Brooklyn in 2017, 2018 :: WRALSportsFan.com] As part of a three-way agreement with Barclays and the ACC, the A-10 will return its men's basketball championship to the Barclays Center in 2019, 2020 and 2021. In 2016, Barclays Center hosted games in the [[2016 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament]] for the first time. Notable moments at the Brooklyn site include a tip-in at the buzzer by Adam Woodbury to lift the [[2015-16 Iowa Hawkeyes men's basketball team|Iowa Hawkeyes]] past [[2015-16 Temple Owls men's basketball team|Temple]] in overtime,{{cite news| url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/woodberrys-rebound-gives-iowa-72-70-ot-win-215503848--ncaab.html |title=Woodbury's rebound gives Iowa 72-70 OT win over Temple |last=O'Connell|first=Jim |location=New York | agency=[[Associated Press]]}} and 14th-seeded [[2015-16 Stephen F. Austin Lumberjacks basketball team|Stephen F. Austin]]'s upset win over [[2015-16 West Virginia Mountaineers men's basketball team|West Virginia]].{{cite news| url=https://sports.yahoo.com/news/walkup-no-14-stephen-f-austin-upset-west-015754618--ncaab.html |title=Walkup, No. 14 Stephen F. Austin upset West Virginia 70-56 |last=Russo|first=Ralph |location=New York | agency=[[Associated Press]]}} ===Hockey=== [[File:Barclays Center - New York Islanders 03.jpg|thumb|right|The New York Islanders playing against the [[Washington Capitals]] in 2016]] The Islanders played the first NHL hockey game at Barclays Center in a preseason game on September 21, 2013, losing to the [[New Jersey Devils]] 3–0 in front of a crowd of 14,689. The first goal in the arena's history was scored by [[Jacob Josefson]] of the New Jersey Devils. An Islanders game was scheduled for the previous preseason but was canceled due to the [[2012–13 NHL lockout]]. The Islanders and Devils played again on September 26, 2014. This time, the Islanders defeated New Jersey 3–2 in a shootout. The first goal in Islanders Brooklyn history was scored in the first period on a power play (and a delayed penalty call) by defenseman [[Ryan Pulock]]. The first regular season game was played on October 9, 2015 against the [[2015 Stanley Cup Finals|2015 Stanley Cup]] champions the [[Chicago Blackhawks]], who won the game 3–2 in overtime. This was the sixth NHL game at Barclays Center, following five total preseason contests (three in 2015), and one Islanders rookie scrimmage. The first NHL regular season goal scored in the Barclays Center was a shorthanded goal by [[Artem Anisimov]] for the Blackhawks in the first period, while [[John Tavares (ice hockey)|John Tavares]] scored in the second period and was the first Islander to do so. The first [[Stanley Cup playoffs]] game at Barclays Center was held on April 17, 2016, when the Islanders defeated the [[Florida Panthers]] 4–3 in game three of the first-round series between the two teams. Seven nights later, the arena hosted game 6 of the series, which turned out to be the longest home game in Islanders history. In that game, the Islanders were trailing 1–0 when Tavares scored the game-tying goal with 53.2 seconds left in regulation; he would score the series-clinching goal in double overtime to give the Islanders their first playoff series win since 1993. ===Boxing, mixed martial arts and pro wrestling=== Several boxing matches have taken place in the arena, including [[Danny Garcia vs. Zab Judah]], and [[Ruslan Provodnikov]] vs. [[Chris Algieri]]. The venue hosted [[UFC 208]] on February 11, 2017 and it hosted [[UFC 223]] on April 7, 2018. The arena has also hosted many [[WWE]] wrestling events, including the PPV ''[[TLC: Tables, Ladders & Chairs (2012)|Tables, Ladders, and Chairs]]'' and several ''[[WWE Raw]]'' episodes (including its [[WWE Raw 25|25th anniversary episode]] in January 2018).{{Cite news|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/sports/features/monday-night-raw-25th-anniversary-wwe-superstar-triple-h-w515638|title=Triple H Is Already Thinking About Tuesday Morning|work=Rolling Stone|access-date=2018-01-23}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.cagesideseats.com/wwe/2018/1/22/16920886/sneak-peak-pics-raw-25-manhattan-center-set-scott-hall|title=Scott Hall gives us a sneak peak of Raw 25’s Manhattan Center set|work=Cageside Seats|access-date=2018-01-23}} In August 2015, Barclays Center hosted [[SummerSlam (2015)|SummerSlam]] (which was originally announced for [[Izod Center]] before its closure), along with [[NXT TakeOver: Brooklyn]] the night before and a post-SummerSlam ''Raw'' the next day,{{Cite news|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/wwe-news/52550-summerslam-2015-seeking-new-location-arena-to-shut-down|title=SummerSlam 2015 seeking new location, arena to shut down|date=2015-01-15|work=Wrestleview|access-date=2018-01-23|language=en-US}} resulting in three consecutive nights of sellouts. On September 28, 2015, WWE announced that SummerSlam would continue to be hosted by Barclays Center in 2016 and 2017, adding a post-SummerSlam ''[[WWE SmackDown|SmackDown Live]]'' broadcast to the events.{{cite web|title=WWE SummerSlam returns to Barclays Center in 2016 and 2017|url=http://www.wwe.com/shows/summerslam/summerslam-barclays-center-brooklyn-2016-2017-27967171|publisher=WWE|accessdate=September 28, 2015}} ===Music=== {{main article|List of concerts at Barclays Center}} In addition to many concerts from a variety of musical acts, the center hosted the [[2013 MTV Video Music Awards]] on August 25, 2013, bringing the show to a New York City borough other than Manhattan for the first time.{{cite web|title=Barclays Center To Host 2013 MTV Video Music Awards |url=http://www.ny1.com/content/ny1_living/entertainment/179301/barclays-center-to-host-2013-mtv-video-music-awards |publisher=NY1 |accessdate=March 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130525144337/http://www.ny1.com/content/ny1_living/entertainment/179301/barclays-center-to-host-2013-mtv-video-music-awards |archivedate=May 25, 2013 }} ===Esports=== In May 2018, [[Blizzard Entertainment]] announced the Grand Finals for the inaugural season of the [[Overwatch League]] would be held at Barclays Center. The event was held on July 27–28, 2018.{{Cite news|url=http://www.espn.com/esports/story/_/id/23445673/barclays-center-host-inaugural-overwatch-league-finals|title=Barclays Center to host Overwatch League finals|work=ESPN.com|access-date=2018-06-14}} ==Issues== ===Legal actions=== During its building, the center was the source of a number of controversies involving local residents, the use of [[eminent domain]], potential environmental impact, lack of continued public financing, as well as a major economic downturn delayed the project. The [[New York Supreme Court]] ruled in favor of Ratner on May 16, 2009.{{Clarify|date=February 2014}} Opponents appealed the court decision, and a hearing for the appeal was scheduled for October 14, 2009, with a decision to be issued no sooner than November 25. On November 24, 2009, the [[New York Court of Appeals]] ruled in favor of the state using eminent domain for the project. [[Empire State Development Corporation]] Vice President Warner Johnston indicated that the agency is committed to seeing the project completed and said "we can now move forward with development." Barclays Center has also been accused of mistreating [[luxury box]] holders who are African-American. Three employees of Ludwig's Pharmacy in Prospect Heights claimed in a lawsuit, filed in October 2013, that they were singled out for bad treatment at the arena just because they are black. They are suing for $4 million.{{cite web|title=Luxury Box Holders Accuse Barclays Center Of Racism, File $4 Million Lawsuit|url=http://gothamist.com/2013/10/31/box_holders_accuse_barclays_center.php|publisher=Gothamist|accessdate=3 November 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131102225014/http://gothamist.com/2013/10/31/box_holders_accuse_barclays_center.php|archivedate=November 2, 2013|df=mdy-all}} ===Labor issues=== A group of 120 part-time construction workers who work to convert the arena from concert hall to sports venue unsuccessfully tried to switch unions in February 2013. The pay for part-time work is structured differently than that of the same work at [[Madison Square Garden]], and workers have complained about not being able to make a living on one-day-a-month work at $14/hour, and being barred from collecting [[unemployment]].{{cite news|url=http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20130228/BLOGS04/130229858|title=Barclays Workers Fail to Break From Union|last=Bragg|first=Chris|date=Feb 28, 2013|publisher=Crain's}} ===Quality as a hockey venue=== [[File:Barclays Center - New York Islanders 02.jpg|thumb|right|Seats with obstructed view]] As the arena was not originally designed with hockey in mind, the New York Islanders' move to Barclays Center has resulted in complaints over seats with obstructed views, and the arena's ice quality. Some seats were singled out for having poor and obstructed sightlines during hockey games.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-best-and-worst-seats-in-hockey-1443832148|title=The Good Views and Bad Views About Barclays Center|last=Raskin|first=Alex|date=October 2, 2015|publisher=Wall Street Journal}} ''[[Business Insider]]'' has called sections 201 to 204 and 228 to 231, "the worst seat in American professional sports".{{cite news|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/barclays-center-new-york-islanders-seats-2015-10|title=Brooklyn's Barclays Center might have the worst seat in American professional sports|last=Garber|first=Jonathan|date=October 12, 2015|work=Business Insider}} In an interview with ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'', Barclays Center CEO Brett Yormark acknowledged the issue, but insisted nothing can be done: "There's really nothing we're going to do from a capital improvement standpoint. You can watch the game on your mobile device. The game is on the scoreboard."{{cite news|url=https://www.si.com/nhl/2016/02/03/new-york-islanders-barclays-center-troubles-brett-yormark-interview|title=Islanders tackling many challenges during first season in Brooklyn|last=Fuchs|first=Jeremy|date=February 3, 2016|work=Sports Illustrated}} There have also been complaints over the quality of the ice during hockey games. The stadium uses PVC piping instead of steel piping under the ice surface, making it much harder to maintain NHL standards and temperature.{{cite news|url=http://www.lighthousehockey.com/2016/10/22/13369316/barclays-center-ice-islanders-complaints|title=In Year 2, Barclays Center Ice Still a Problem|date=October 22, 2016|work=lighthousehockey.com}} {{clear}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Barclays Center}} *{{Official website|http://www.barclayscenter.com}} {{s-start}} {{EngvarB|date=July 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2016}} [[File:WallendbeenCricketGround.JPG|thumb|240px|A cricket oval in [[Wallendbeen]], [[New South Wales]] with a white [[picket fence]], traditionally used as the boundary]] In [[cricket]] a '''boundary''' is the edge or boundary of the playing field, or a scoring shot where the ball is hit to or beyond that point.
==Edge of the field== The '''boundary''' is the edge of the playing field, or the physical object marking the edge of the field, such as a rope or fence. In low-level matches, a series of plastic cones are often used. Since the early 2000s the boundaries at professional matches are often a series of padded cushions carrying sponsors' logos strung along a rope. If it is moved during play (such as by a fielder sliding into the rope) the boundary is considered to remain at the point where that object first stood. [[Image:Boundary rope.jpg|thumb|right|240px|A traditional boundary rope]] When the [[cricket ball]] is inside the boundary, it is live. When the ball is touching the boundary, grounded beyond the boundary, or being touched by a [[fielding positions in cricket|fielder]] who is himself either touching the boundary or grounded beyond it, it is [[Dead ball#Cricket|dead]] and the batting side usually scores 4 or 6 runs for hitting the ball over the boundary. Because of this rule, fielders near the boundary attempting to intercept the ball while running or diving, often flick the ball back in to the field of play rather than pick it up directly, because their momentum could carry them beyond the rope while holding the ball. They then return to the field to pick the ball up and throw it back to the bowler.
A law change in 2010 declared that a fielder could not jump from behind the boundary and, while airborne, parry the ball back on to the field.<ref>{{cite web|title=Explanation of the changes between the 3rd Edition and 4th Edition of the 2000 Code of the Laws of Cricket|url=http://www.mbromcl.org.uk/lawchanges.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=October 2010 Laws of cricket changes – Ball over the boundary|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tkq_kBUi13c|work=Lords Cricket Ground|accessdate=14 November 2013}}</ref>
==Scoring runs== A '''boundary''' is the scoring of four or six [[run (cricket)|runs]] from a single delivery with the ball reaching or crossing the boundary of the playing field. Occasionally there is an erroneous use of the term boundary as a synonym for a "four". For example, sometimes commentators say such as ''"There were seven boundaries and three sixes in the innings."'' The correct terminology would be ''"There were ten boundaries in the innings of which seven were fours and three were sixes". ''
Four runs are scored if the ball bounces before touching or going over the edge of the field and six runs if it does not bounce before passing over the boundary in the air. These events are known as a '''four''' or a '''six''' respectively. When this happens the runs are automatically added to the batsman's and his team's score and the ball becomes [[dead ball (cricket)|dead]]. If the ball did not touch the bat or a hand holding the bat, four runs are scored as the relevant type of [[extra (cricket)|extra]] instead; six runs cannot be scored as extras, even if the ball clears the boundary, which is in any case extremely unlikely. Prior to 1910, six runs were only awarded for hits out of the ground.<ref>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/magazine/content/story/234084.html "Ask Steven", 23 January 2006] Retrieved 7 July 2011</ref>
Four runs (or more) can also be scored by hitting the ball into the outfield and running between the [[wicket]]s. Four runs scored in this way is referred to as an 'all run four' and is not counted as a boundary.
Four runs are scored as overthrows if a fielder gathers the ball and then throws it so that no other fielder can gather it before it reaches the boundary. In this case, the batsman who hit the ball scores however many runs the batsmen had run up to that time, plus four additional runs, and it is counted as a boundary. If the ball has not come off the bat or hand holding the bat, then the runs are classified as 'extras' and are added to the team's score but not to the score of any individual batsman. [[File:Cricket at Chrishall - geograph.org.uk - 1407180.jpg|thumb|240px|A batsman scoring a six during a game at [[Chrishall]], Essex]] The scoring of a four or six by a good aggressive shot displays a certain amount of mastery by the batsman over the bowler, and is usually greeted by applause from the spectators. Fours resulting from an edged stroke, or from a shot that did not come off as the batsman intended, are considered bad luck to the bowler. As a batsman plays himself in and becomes more confident as his innings progresses, the proportion of his runs scored in boundaries often rises.
An average first-class match usually sees between 50 and 150 boundary fours.{{Citation needed|date=June 2007}} Sixes are less common, and usually fewer than 10 (and sometimes none) will be scored in the course of a match (especially a [[Test cricket|Test match]]).
==Records==
===Sixes=== The record for most sixes in a Test match innings is 12, which was achieved by [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistani]] all-rounder [[Wasim Akram]] during an innings of 257 not out against [[Zimbabwe national cricket team|Zimbabwe]] in October 1996 at [[Sheikhupura Stadium|Sheikhupura]]. The [[One Day International]] record for most sixes hit in an innings is held by [[Rohit Sharma]] who hit 16 sixes against Australia in [[Bengaluru]] on 2 November 2013 in his innings of 209 off 158 balls.
[[Brendon McCullum]] currently holds the record for most sixes in a Test career with 107.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283122.html|title=Records – Test matches – Batting records – Most sixes in career – ESPN Cricinfo|work=Cricinfo}}</ref> [[Shahid Afridi]] holds the record for [[most sixes in an ODI career]] (351 in 398 matches, 369 innings, on his retirement).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://stats.cricinfo.com/ci/content/records/283123.html|title=Records – One-Day Internationals – Batting records – Most sixes in career – ESPN Cricinfo|work=Cricinfo}}</ref> <gallery> Shahid Afridi 2010.jpg|Shahid Afridi holds world record for most sixes in ODIs. </gallery> The record for the most sixes in a Test match is 27, which occurred during a 2006 Test match between [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] and [[India national cricket team|India]] at the [[Iqbal Stadium]] in [[Faisalabad]]. In their first innings, Pakistan hit eleven sixes. India hit nine in their first innings. Pakistan hit seven more sixes in their second innings.
The record for most sixes in a One Day International is 38, which was achieved in a match between [[India national cricket team|India]] and [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] at [[Bengaluru|M Chinnaswamy Stadium]] on 2 November 2013. India and Australia hit 19 sixes each. The equivalent record in [[Twenty20 International]]s was set on the [[Lancaster Park|AMI Stadium]], 24 sixes were hit during the Twenty20 International match between India and New Zealand on 25 February 2009.
In 2012, during the [[West Indian cricket team in Bangladesh in 2012–13|First Test against Bangladesh]] in Dhaka, West Indies cricketer [[Chris Gayle]] became the first player to hit a six off the first ball in a Test cricket match.<ref name="BBCGayle">{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/20316154 |title=West Indies' Chris Gayle creates Test history with opening six |accessdate=14 November 2012|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>
[[File:MCG stands yellow seat.jpg|thumb|At the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|MCG]] a yellow seat marks the biggest six hit at the ground.]]
===6 sixes in an over=== On 31 August 1968, [[Garfield Sobers]] became the first man to hit six sixes off a single six-ball [[over (cricket)|over]] in [[first-class cricket]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/152407.html|title=Wisden – Notes by the Editor|work=Cricinfo}}</ref> The over was bowled by [[Malcolm Nash]] in [[Nottinghamshire County Cricket Club|Nottinghamshire's]] first innings against [[Glamorgan County Cricket Club|Glamorgan]] at [[St. Helen's Rugby and Cricket Ground|St Helen's]] in [[Swansea]]. Nash was a [[seam bowling|seam bowler]] but decided to try his arm at [[spin bowling]]. This achievement was caught on film.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=l1TqVCDgH6M|title=YouTube|publisher=}}</ref>
On 16 March 2007, in a match between [[South African cricket team|South Africa]] and the [[Dutch cricket team|Netherlands]] at the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]], [[Herschelle Gibbs]] became the first person to hit six sixes off an over in a [[One Day International]] match. The over was bowled by Dutch [[leg-spin]]ner [[Daan van Bunge]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/6453331.stm|publisher=BBC Sport|title=Gibbs matches Sobers in easy win|date=16 March 2007}}</ref>
On 24 April 2013, in a second XI game for [[Lancashire]] against [[Yorkshire]] at Scarborough, [[Jordan Clark (cricketer)|Jordan Clark]] hit six sixes off left-arm spinner Gurham Randhawa.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/cricket/22284876|title=Jordan Clark: Lancashire batsman hits six sixes at Scarborough|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>
On 8 July 2015, Victorian all-rounder [[Marcus Stoinis]] hit part-time medium-pacer Brendan Smith for six sixes in an over on his way to 121 from 73 balls while playing for the National Performance Squad in a 50-over match against a National Indigenous Squad. Smith, captain of the New South Wales under-17s, also sent down a wide meaning his one over of the match went for 37 runs. The game was a non-sanctioned practice match.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cricket.com.au/news/six-sixes-in-an-over-marcus-stoinis-brendan-smith-allan-border-field-nps/2015-07-08|title=Stoinis smashes six sixes in an over|publisher=Cricket Australia |accessdate=15 July 2015}}</ref>
On 23 July 2017, Worcestershire Rapid's [[Ross Whiteley]] hit 6 sixes off six legal deliveries plus one wide to take the total number of runs in that over to 37 off bowler [[Karl Carver]] at [[Headingley Cricket Ground|Headingley]]. That achievement did not help [[Worcestershire CCC|Worcestershire Rapids]] beat the [[Yorkshire Vikings]] as the [[Yorkshire Vikings]] won by 37 runs after [[David Willey (cricketer)|David Willey]] smashed 118.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/cricket/news/12123/10959195/natwest-t20-blast-ross-whiteley-hits-six-sixes-in-over-for-worcester|title=NatWest T20 Blast: Ross Whiteley hits six sixes in over for Worcester|author=|date=|website=skysports.com|accessdate=9 April 2018}}</ref>
In October 2018 Afghan player [[Hazratullah Zazai]] hit 6 sixes in an over, becoming the third ever batsman to do so in a Twenty20.<ref>https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/av/cricket/45862488</ref>

revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=September 2018}}'''''Caid''''' ({{IPA-ga|kadʲ}}) is the name given to various ancient and traditional [[Ireland|Irish]] [[football]] games. "Caid" is now used by people in some parts of Ireland to refer to modern [[Gaelic football]].
The word ''caid'' originally referred to the [[football (ball)|ball]] which was used. It was made out of animal skin, with a natural bladder inside.
''Caid'' is believed to have influenced the modern sport of [[Gaelic football]] the rules of which were officially published in 1887 and is now organised and governed by the [[Gaelic Athletic Association]] (GAA) as an amateur sport.
There is some evidence that ''caid'' was taken around the world by the [[Irish diaspora]], and some historians argue that it may have also played some part in the [[origins of Australian rules football]], although [[Relationship between Gaelic football and Australian rules football|such a relationship is controversial and the subject of debate]].
==History== The first recorded mention of football in Ireland was in 1308, when John McCrocan, a spectator at a football game at [[Newcastle, County Down]], was charged with accidentally stabbing a player named William Bernard. Football games are mentioned in the ''[[Statute of Galway]]'', 1527, which allowed the playing of football and [[archery]], but banned "'hokie' — the hurling of a little ball with sticks or staves", as well as other sports. The [[List of Acts of the Parliament of Ireland to 1700|Sunday Observance Act of 1695]] imposed a fine of one shilling for anyone found playing. Despite this, the earliest recorded football match in Ireland was one between [[County Louth|Louth]] and [[County Meath|Meath]], at [[Slane]], in 1712.
''Caid'' was especially popular in rural areas, such as the [[Dingle Peninsula]] of [[County Kerry|Kerry]]<ref>Thesis – “Traditional game of Caid”, Father W. Ferris of Glenflesk, Killarney, Ireland.</ref> and [[Eigeen]] in west Cork. One observer in the mid-19th century, Father W. Ferris, described two main forms of ''caid'' during this period: the "field game" in which the object was to put the ball through arch-like goals, formed from the boughs of two trees, and; the epic "cross-country game" which took up most of the daylight hours of a Sunday on which it was played, and was won by one team taking the ball across a parish boundary. Both of these were rough and tumble [[contact sport]]s in which "wrestling", pushing and the [[tackle (football move)|holding]] of opposing players was allowed. It was usually played by teams of unlimited numbers, representing communities, until a clear result was achieved or the players became too exhausted to continue.
These games appear to have been similar to the traditional [[Wales|Welsh]] game of ''[[cnapan]]'', which was played by teams of up to 1,000 men from adjacent parishes. ''Cnapan'', however, was played with a hard ball and thus involved no kicking; it was strictly a game in which the ball was passed or smuggled from one player to another, with the object of getting it to the opposing team's parish church porch or to some other agreed destination. An inter parish mob football game similar to ''cnapan'' called [[Cornish hurling|''Hyrlîan'']] (In English ''Hurling'') is still played in [[Cornwall]] on dates that coincide with religious festivals such as [[Shrove Tuesday]].
By the late 19th century, ''caid'' was in steep decline and was threatened with extinction, spurring the formation of the GAA which published official rules for the game in 1887 also adopting aspects of the earlier codified sport - [[hurling]].

{{refimprove|date=December 2015}} {{Infobox organization | name = Challenged Athletes Foundation | logo = | type = 501c3 Non-profit | founded_date = {{start date and age|1997}} | tax_id = 33-0739596 | registration_id = | founder = [[Jim MacLaren]] | location = 9591 Waples Street
San Diego, CA | origins = | key_people = | area_served = | product = | mission = | focus = | method = | revenue = $3,695,032 | endowment = $425,000 | num_volunteers = | num_employees = | num_members = | subsid = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = Recognizing courage. Rewarding perseverance. Realizing dreams. | former name = | homepage = http://www.challengedathletes.org | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Challenged Athletes Foundation''' ('''CAF'''), established in 1997, assists, supports, and provides opportunity to people with physical challenges, so that they can lead active lifestyles and compete in athletic events.{{cite web|title=Challenged Athletes Foundation|url=http://www.challengedathletes.org/|website=Challenged Athletes Foundation}} It is founded in the belief that involvement in sports at any level increases self-esteem, encourages independence and enhances quality of life. The Foundation does this by providing funding for training, competition, [[Physical therapy|rehabilitation]], and [[Sports equipment|equipment]] for the challenged athletes. The Challenged Athletes Foundation is divided into four different programs: Access for Athletes, Operation Rebound, Catch a Rising Star, and Project N.Ex.T., all of which focus on the betterment of disabled athletes, but vary in their target group. Access for Athletes is the flagship program of CAF. == History == Challenged Athletes Foundation was founded in 1997 in response to [[Amputation|below-knee-amputee]] [[Ultramarathon|endurance racer]] [[Jim MacLaren]] who suffered an accident while competing in a [[triathlon]]. In June 1993, while competing in a triathlon in Orange County, California, MacLaren was on his bike when a van went through a closed intersection, hit the back of the bike and propelled him into a pole. When he arrived at the hospital he was told that he was a quadriplegic and would never move again from the waist down.{{citation needed|date=March 2017}} == Programs and Events == === Programs === The following are programs which CAF offers or supports: * Access for Athletes – this is CAF’s flagship program. It provides funding for equipment, training and travel expenses. In 2011, Access for Athletes satisfied 980 funding requests from challenged athletes in 45 U.S. states and 22 countries. The grants, totaling more than $1.4 million, were used by recipients – of all ages, from beginners to elites – to participate in 47 different sports. * Catch a Rising Star – is a program that provides fun, interactive, nurturing clinics – led by recognized experts and authorities – that provide instruction in basic sports skills. These clinics, which include mentoring from elite CAF athletes, allow participants to develop the confidence and self-esteem required to reach their individual goals. In 2011, CAF held 23 clinics and camps across the United States, reaching 495 physically challenged athletes. * Reach High – is a program provides information, resources and opportunities to people with physical challenges, enabling them to make informed decisions about health, lifestyle and medical choices. The program also raises awareness within the broader community about the abilities of athletes with physical challenges. * Operation Rebound – CAF is a member organization of Operation Rebound, a sports and fitness program for American military personnel, veterans and first responders with permanent physical disabilities. In 2011, CAF Operation Rebound provided 240 grants injured troops and first responders and supported an additional 80 individuals through its Military Medical Center Physical Training Program and CAF events. * Project N.Ex.T. (New Expectations Today) – is a three-year San Diego County pilot program that connects physically challenged mentees with similarly challenged mentors. By educating recently injured or inactive individuals about available fitness and sports opportunities, we believe we can create better and more consistent outcomes for Project N.Ex.T. participants. === Events === The Challenged Athletes Foundation holds a number of high-profile fund raising events in order to raise money to support disabled athletes to compete in sports. These include CAF events the San Diego Triathlon Challenge; Million Dollar Challenge; Heroes, Heart and Hope Gala held at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel|Waldorf Astoria]] in [[New York City]], Hawaii Revisited; Tour de Cove; Rock on the Green and numerous other events under the banner of Race for a Reason.{{Citation needed|date=February 2011}} == Athletes == The Challenged Athletes Foundation has enabled a number of disabled athletes to get to the starting line. Amongst these are [[Sarah Reinertsen]] who was the first female leg amputee to complete the [[Ironman Triathlon World Championships]] in [[Kona, Hawaii]]. Other well-known challenged athletes include: *[[Emmanuel Ofosu Yeboah]] *[[Rudy Garcia-Tolson]] *[[Evan Strong]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.challengedathletes.org Challenged Athletes Foundation's Official Website] * [http://www.facebook.com/CAForg?ref=search&sid=554895536.2572994680..1 The Main Challenged Athletes Foundation's Official Facebook Group] * [http://www.challengedathletes.org/florida/ CAF's Florida Chapter] * [http://www.facebook.com/CAFFlorida#!/ CAF's Florida Chapter Official Facebook Group] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in California]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Florida]] [[Category:Disabled sports organizations]] [[Category:Disability organizations based in the United States]]

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Challenger Columbia Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = 2145 West Nasa Boulevard
[[League City, Texas]] 77573 | coordinates = {{Coord|29.5183|-95.1355|type:landmark_region:US-TX|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = 26 March 2014{{Cite web|url = http://www.chron.com/neighborhood/bayarea/news/article/Clear-Creek-ISD-breaks-ground-for-second-stadium-5366908.php|title = Clear Creek ISD breaks ground for second stadium|date = 1 April 2014 |accessdate = 27 July 2015|website = Chron|publisher = Hearst Newspapers|last = |first = }} | opened = 10 March 2016 | closed = | demolished = | renovated = | owner = [[Clear Creek Independent School District|Clear Creek ISD]] | operator = [[Clear Creek Independent School District|Clear Creek ISD]] | surface =Synthetic turf | construction_cost = $39,079,651{{Cite web|url = http://www.ccisd.net/departments/facility-services/2013-bond-construction/challenger-columbia-stadium-bond-updates|title = CCISD Challenger Columbia Stadium|date = |accessdate = 27 July 2015|website = 2013 Bond|publisher = Clear Creek ISD|last = |first = }} | architect =[[PBK Architects]] | general_contractor= | former_names =Second District Stadium (planning) | tenants = [[Clear Brook High School]]
[[Clear Creek High School (League City, Texas)|Clear Creek High School]]
[[Clear Falls High School]]
[[Clear Lake High School (Houston, Texas)|Clear Lake High School]]
[[Clear Springs High School]] | seating_capacity = 10,000 | record_attendance = | scoreboard =34' by 19' LED screen ||website = [http://www.ccisdchallengercolumbia.com/home.html Challenger Columbia Stadium] }} '''Challenger Columbia Stadium''' is a multi-purpose stadium in [[League City, Texas]]. It is the second stadium in the [[Clear Creek Independent School District]] (CCISD) and serves all five of its comprehensive 6A high schools. The stadium was built to relieve the overused and deficient [[Veterans Memorial Stadium (League City)|Veterans Memorial Stadium]] and end the frequently scheduled Thursday night football games for all the CCISD high schools.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ccisdchallengercolumbia.com/about-the-stadium.html|title = About Challenger Columbia Stadium|date = |accessdate = 26 July 2015|website = Challenger Columbia Stadium|publisher = Clear Creek ISD|last = |first = }}{{Cite web|url = http://www.yourhoustonnews.com/deer_park/sports/challenger-columbia-stadium-launch-delayed/article_9f4d9d1a-6ded-5689-b52b-70168b719f18.html|title = Challenger-Columbia stadium launch delayed|date = 16 July 2015|accessdate = 26 July 2015|website = Deer Park Broadcaster|publisher = Your Houston News|last = Dunnam|first = Ted}} == History == CCISD's Veterans Memorial Stadium was built in the 1950s at [[Clear Creek High School (League City, Texas)|Clear Creek High School]] to serve the one 3A high school in the district at the time. Since then, the district has grown tremendously, opening four more high schools. Since 2000 alone, the district has built two high schools, opening [[Clear Springs High School]] in 2007 and [[Clear Falls High School]] in 2010. With five 6A high schools to serve, Veterans Memorial Stadium is unable to fully handle the load, leading to numerous Thursday football games. Events at Veterans Memorial, in turn, increase traffic and congestion at the neighboring CCISD facilities and residential area. Stadium parking overflows into the parking lots at Clear Creek High School, Clear Creek Intermediate, the CCISD Education Support Center, and neighboring businesses and residences. The traffic also affects the already congested Five Corners of League City, where the stadium is located.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ccisd.net/2013-bond-election/faqs|title = 2013 Bond FAQs|date = |accessdate = 26 July 2013|website = |publisher = Clear Creek ISD|last = |first = }} Clear Creek ISD held a bond election on 11 May 2013 with the construction of a second district stadium as a major item. The bond was approved with 68% in favor. The 2013 Bond also calls for the rebuilding of multiple campuses in the district and major construction at others, along with the introduction of improved technological learning.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ccisd.net/2013-bond|title = 2013 Bond|date = |accessdate = 26 July 2015|website = 2013 Bond|publisher = Clear Creek ISD|last = |first = }} The stadium broke ground on 26 March 2014 at a ceremony with family members of the Challenger and Columbia crews and members of various CCISD extracurricular activities (football, band, cheerleading, track, etc.) present. Challenger Columbia Stadium was originally scheduled for completion in mid-2015, in time for the 2015 high school football season. However, heavy rains in the Houston-area throughout the spring of 2015 led to construction delays. Clear Creek ISD eventually determined that the stadium would not be done in time for the 2015 season, and the schedules for the five high schools had to be changed and consolidated back to only one stadium, Veterans Memorial Stadium.{{Cite web|url=http://www.yourhoustonnews.com/deer_park/sports/challenger-columbia-stadium-launch-delayed/article_9f4d9d1a-6ded-5689-b52b-70168b719f18.html|title=Challenger-Columbia stadium launch delayed|last=Dunnam|first=Todd|date=|website=Deer Park Broadcaster|publisher=Your Houston News|publication-date=16 July 2015|access-date=11 March 2016}} After multiple delays, Challenger Columbia Stadium opened in March 2016 with an official dedication on 10 March 2016. The dedication ceremony included the athletes, bands, and cheerleaders from the five high schools and tributes to the crew members lost in the Challenger and Columbia disasters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.click2houston.com/news/clear-creek-isd-dedicates-stadium-in-memory-of-challenger-columbia-astronauts|title=Clear Creek ISD dedicates stadium in memory of Challenger, Columbia astronauts|last=Martinez|first=Jonathan|website=KPRC|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-11}} [[File:Challenger flight 51-l crew.jpg|thumb|Crew of [[STS-51-L]] ([[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Challenger disaster]])]] == Naming == [[File:Crew of STS-107, official photo.jpg|thumb|Crew of [[STS-107]] ([[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Columbia disaster]])]] CCISD serves the [[Clear Lake (region)|Clear Lake]] area, including the area directly around [[NASA]]'s [[Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center|Johnson Space Center]]. The stadium site is also located adjacent to the Challenger Seven Memorial Park. The district chose the name Challenger Columbia Stadium to honor the 14 astronauts who lost their lives in the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Challenger disaster]] in 1986 and the [[Space Shuttle Columbia disaster|Columbia disaster]] in 2003.{{Cite web|url = http://www.ccisd.net/ccisd-challenger-columbia-stadium/about-our-heroes|title = About Our Heroes|date = |accessdate = 26 July 2015|website = Challenger Columbia Stadium|publisher = Clear Creek ISD|last = |first = }} Clear Creek ISD broke ground on Challenger Columbia stadium on 26 March 2014 with family members of some of the lost crew members in attendance.{{Cite web|url = http://www.yourhoustonnews.com/bay_area/news/clear-creek-isd-s-challenger-columbia-stadium-to-pay-tribute/article_2b41a736-3c1a-5558-bb02-dfc37c7eddec.html|title = Clear Creek ISD’s Challenger Columbia Stadium to pay tribute to fallen crews|date = 1 April 2014|accessdate = 26 July 2015|website = Bay Area The Citizen|publisher = Your Houston News|last = Orozoco|first = Y.C.}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== * [http://www.ccisdchallengercolumbia.com/home.html Stadium Website] * [http://ccisd.net/ Clear Creek ISD] {{Clear Creek ISD}} {{League City, Texas}} [[Category:Sports venues in Texas]] [[Category:League City, Texas]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Galveston County, Texas]] [[Category:Clear Creek Independent School District]] [[Category:2016 establishments in Texas]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2016]] [[Category:American football venues in Texas]] [[Category:High school football venues in Texas]] [[Category:Soccer venues in Texas]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Texas]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Chennai veerans logo.png|right]] The '''Chennai Veerans''' was a Tier-1 level [[field hockey]] team [[Premier Hockey League]] in [[India]]. In the inaugural cup in 2005, the ''Chennai Veerans'' led by [[Ignace Tirkey]] finished at the bottom of the group with two wins and six losses.
After finishing at the bottom of the premier division in the inaugural PHL in year 2005, Chennai Veerans were relegated to Tier-II division of PHL in 2006, where they played along with [[Orissa Steelers]], Lucknow Nawabs, Delhi Dazzlers and Imphal Rangers. In this league Chennai Veerans finished runners-up to Orissa Steelers. It was later decided that in 2007 no team should be relegated from Tier I. Instead 2 teams were added to the premier division [Tier-I]. So 7 teams entered the current Tier-I of 3rd PHL-2007 - 1) Sher-e-jalandhar, 2) Orissa Steelers, 3) [[Bangalore Lions]], 4) [[Maratha Warriors]], 5) Chennai Veerans, 6) Chandigarh Dynamos, and the Tier-II division was scrapped for the year 2007 by the IHF.
